channel.title: Obtaining a programming job
channel.description:
Your's or someone else's experiences, the ins, the outs, the hows, the whos.
Any help would be appreciated.

item.title: Obtaining a programming job
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

There are many gigs available for DIYers or small businesses looking to have an application developed, or to put themselves on the web. A simple one page website with contact information can be sold for $100. And it gets better from there. Elance and Freelancer are good places to start if you spend the right amount of time selling yourself.

Read full topic

item.title: Obtaining a programming job
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

Any real company won’t just hire you unless you have a resume that shows you know what the hell you’re doing. But you can start off at an entry level position answering phone calls and working with technical issues and work your way in.

Read full topic

item.title: Obtaining a programming job
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:3, topic:548611”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=667521.msg4464136#msg4464136 date=1419099007]
do u have any degrees or certs
[/quote]
Idk about him, but I don’t… Is there such thing as “entry level” programming jobs? I mean I do know shit about programming, but it’s nothing that has a degree or etc behind it.[/quote]
There is. I was a Jr Software Developer with no previous experience, I most likely know less about programming than you & I had not so good grades. That being said my CV & interview skills are good, I have a portfolio and I of course have a decent value of desirable traits.
It wasn’t easy though, often I got told to do things with no support (because they didn’t have time to help) that having a good education would have helped with for sure. At other times it sucked too, doing the same testing over and over again for literally 3+ days, writing interfaces/re-factoring code (inc thinking you made a mistake then going through it but finding out it was someone else updated code and that part of the program/site no longer functioned = days wasted) and so on.

But being pushed is good of course; I learned a hell of a lot, earned money, gained a good reference (I’m back in education now) & have the option to go back their in the future.

Read full topic

item.title: Obtaining a programming job
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:11, topic:548611”][quote author=t4 link=topic=667521.msg4464500#msg4464500 date=1419294550]
Know your basics like data structures and algorithms. OO and language concepts come too (ex: what is a virtual destructor). Try looking for the Cracking the Code book, it’s a good way to prep for interviews. All the places I’ve worked at will laugh at you if you don’t have a degree or at least significant experience. There’s tons of poseurs/climbers out there, look at moparscape.
[/quote]
If there wasn’t a degree, how much experience would they expect?[/quote]
Like 5-10 years+ job experience

Read full topic

item.title: Obtaining a programming job
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Thanks for all the feedback! I’m getting the general idea that if you can fluently express the basics, they are down with that. I do have to build se confidence behind my abilities, but I think as soon as I get back to school, I should have no problems figuring out a possible career.

Read full topic

Know your basics like data structures and algorithms. OO and language concepts come too (ex: what is a virtual destructor). Try looking for the Cracking the Code book, it’s a good way to prep for interviews. All the places I’ve worked at will laugh at you if you don’t have a degree or at least significant experience. There’s tons of poseurs/climbers out there, look at moparscape.

Know your basics like data structures and algorithms. OO and language concepts come too (ex: what is a virtual destructor). Try looking for the Cracking the Code book, it’s a good way to prep for interviews. All the places I’ve worked at will laugh at you if you don’t have a degree or at least significant experience. item.title: Obtaining a programming job
item.dc:creator: @Vix Vix
item.description:
@Vix wrote:

The need for programmers is in rather high demand right now since many companies are currently looking for websites and applications. I’ve done internships with a few local software development companies who really stressed that a large part of obtaining the job is how well you work and interact with others since almost all projects are done in small groups and managed by a single individual. The general stereotype of a programmer is a socially awkward person who doesn’t interact well with others, most companies won’t hire someone like this because they worry that person could slow down development because of an inability to communicate. Education is very important too don’t think i’m hinting that it isn’t, but ten degrees still wont seal the deal if you cant make eye contact with your interviewer.

If your sporting a 2+ year degree from either a college or trade school, work well in groups, and are enthusiastic (or at-least pretend to be) about the job your applying for you should be alright.

Read full topic

item.title: Obtaining a programming job
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

I’ve worked got Xerox, Amazon, Microsoft, and Nordstrom. All you really have to do is know your stuff for the job you’re applying for. Generally, phone screens ask you the basic questions. If it’s an SDE role, it’s mostly C#/Java questions, if it’s an SDET role, there will be testing questions as well (what unit testing is, test driven development, what to test given a certain situation, etc). How to implement certain algorithms, like Stack, Linked List, cyclical linked lists, how to implement a certain function iteratively or recursively (ie. calculating a specific fibonacci number), what the difference is, why you would choose one over the other. If you don’t know something, be honest. “How would you implement an ecommerce website with Angular?”, if you don’t know the technology, state it. Employers hate nothing more than believing you know a technology, and then finding out you’re incompetent when they ask you to do something.

Once you get in, you’ll likely be working in an Agile/Scrum lifecycle, so knowing what the basic process is would help. But most of my experience is in enterprise systems. I haven’t had a lot of experience in little 1-2 person dev shops.

Read full topic

item.title: Obtaining a programming job
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

I’ve only had minor programming classes in college. I have done a few small web projects mostly for people that I have met over the years. The only way it came about is when I give my email to people they see its at a top level domain. There is a surprisingly number of businesses out there that want to be online but can’t afford top dollar web development firms. Although I don’t really enjoy the work I don’t see where it should be too hard for you to freelance your way into something bigger.

Read full topic

item.title: Obtaining a programming job
item.dc:creator: @Kiryn Kiryn
item.description:
@Kiryn wrote:

I myself have not obtained any job related to computer science (I’m a software development major going for my associates) my peer(s); however, the same age as me (20) has an entry level job doing html/javascript stuff for JP morgan

Read full topic

item.title: Obtaining a programming job
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:3, topic:548611”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=667521.msg4464136#msg4464136 date=1419099007]
do u have any degrees or certs
[/quote]
Idk about him, but I don’t… Is there such thing as “entry level” programming jobs? I mean I do know shit about programming, but it’s nothing that has a degree or etc behind it.[/quote]

Sure there are. I am in co-op at my university and even many first years got jobs and internships. Realistically it may not be as much programming as you would like (such as testing and QA jobs) but typically this is what you start doing if you don’t have a solid portfolio or are just starting school for your major. However, I knew lots of people who had actual programming positions and even some who had pretty important tasks assigned to them. It’s definitely possible, you just need to network effectively. The great thing about doing a co-op at your school is that the network is already setup for you and applying to jobs are easy.

Read full topic
